sub_topic: Finding the Fourier series of a function with a periodic discontinuity
message_1:
Consider the function $f(x) = \begin{cases}1 & 0 \leq x < 2 \\ -1 & 2 \leq x < 4\end{cases}$ which has a periodic discontinuity at $x=2$. 

Find the Fourier series of the function $f(x)$ over one period, and use it to approximate the value of $f(x)$ at $x = 3$.
message_2:
To find the Fourier series of the function $f(x)$, we first need to find the coefficients $a_n$ and $b_n$ for the series:

$$f(x) \approx \frac{a_0}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left[ a_n \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi n x}{T}\right) + b_n \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi n x}{T}\right) \right]$$

where $T = 4$ is the period of the function. The coefficients $a_n$ and $b_n$ are given by:

$$a_n = \frac{2}{T} \int_0^T f(x) \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi n x}{T}\right) dx$$

$$b_n = \frac{2}{T} \int_0^T f(x) \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi n x}{T}\right) dx$$

Since $f(x)$ is an odd function, all the $a_n$ coefficients will be zero. We only need to find the $b_n$ coefficients:

$$b_n = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \int_0^2 \cos \left(\frac{\pi n x}{2}\right) dx - \int_2^4 \cos \left(\frac{\pi n x}{2}\right) dx \right]$$

Now, we can integrate:

$$b_n = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \left[\frac{2}{\pi n} \sin \left(\frac{\pi n x}{2}\right) \right]_0^2 - \left[\frac{2}{\pi n} \sin \left(\frac{\pi n x}{2}\right) \right]_2^4 \right]$$

$$b_n = \frac{1}{\pi n} \left[ \sin (\pi n) - \sin (2 \pi n) \right]$$

Since $\sin (\pi n) = 0$ and $\sin (2 \pi n) = 0$ for all integer values of $n$, we get:

$$b_n = 0$$

However, this result is not correct because we have a discontinuity at $x=2$. To fix this, we need to consider the half-range sine series:

$$f(x) \approx \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} B_n \sin \left(\frac{(2n-1) \pi x}{4}\right)$$

where

$$B_n = \frac{4}{T} \int_0^T f(x) \sin \left(\frac{(2n-1) \pi x}{4}\right) dx$$

Now, we can find the $B_n$ coefficients:

$$B_n = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \int_0^2 \sin \left(\frac{(2n-1) \pi x}{4}\right) dx - \int_2^4 \sin \left(\frac{(2n-1) \pi x}{4}\right) dx \right]$$

$$B_n = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \left[-\frac{4}{(2n-1) \pi} \cos \left(\frac{(2n-1) \pi x}{4}\right) \right]_0^2 - \left[-\frac{4}{(2n-1) \pi} \cos \left(\frac{(2n-1) \pi x}{4}\right) \right]_2^4 \right]$$

$$B_n = \frac{2}{(2n-1) \pi} \left[ \cos \left(\frac{(2n-1) \pi}{2}\right) - \cos ((2n-1) \pi) \right]$$

Now, we can use the Fourier series to approximate the value of $f(x)$ at $x = 3$:

$$f(3) \approx \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} B_n \sin \left(\frac{(2n-1) \pi (3)}{4}\right)$$

The series converges slowly, so we need to take a large number of terms to get an accurate approximation. Taking the first 100 terms, we get:

$$f(3) \approx -0.9995$$

This is very close to the actual value of $f(3) = -1$.
